Prove that there exists an absolute constant $c>0$ such that, whenever $\{1,\ldots,N\}$ is $k$-coloured (and $N$ is large enough depending on $k$) then there are at least $cN$ many integers in $\{1,\ldots,N\}$ which are representable as a monochromatic sum (that is, $a+b$ where $a,b\in \{1,\ldots,N\}$ are in the same colour class and $a\neq b$).



A conjecture of Roth.

Solved by Erd\H{o}s, S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy, and S\'{o}s \cite{ESS89}, who in fact prove that there are at least\[\frac{N}{2}-O(N^{1-1/2^{k+1}})\]many even numbers which are of this form. They also prove that if $k=2$ then there are at least\[\frac{N}{2}-O(\log N)\]many even numbers which are of this form, and that $O(\log N)$ is best possible, since there is a $2$-colouring such that no power of $2$ is representable as a monochromatic sum.

A refinement of this problem appears as Problem 25 on the open problems list of Ben Green.




References


[ESS89] Erd\H{o}s, P. and S\'{a}rk\"ozy, A. and S\'{o}s, V. T., On a conjecture of {R}oth and some related problems. I. (1989), 47--59.
